'Peak oil' is the point in time
when the maximum rate of petroleum extraction is reached, after which the rate
of production is expected to enter terminal decline. {{cite web |url= http://lexicon.ft.com/Term?term=peak-
oil |title=peak oil definition from Financial Times Lexicon |work= Financial
Times Lexicon |year=2012 |accessdate=21 May 2012}} Global production of
oil fell from a high point in 2005 at 74 mb/d, but has since rebounded, and 2011
figures show slightly higher levels of production than in 2005. [http://www-
.eia.gov/cfapps/ipdbproject/iedindex3.cfm?tid=5&pid=57&aid=1&cid=regions&syid=2-
005&eyid=2011&unit=TBPD International Energy Statistics] There is active
debate as to how to measure peak oil, and which types of liquid fuels to
include. Most of the remaining oil is from unconventional sources. Rough
estimates indicate that out of an available 2 trillion barrels of oil, about
half has been consumed.

Peak oil is determined by the observed production rates of individual oil wells,
projected reserves and the combined production rate of a field of related oil
wells. In order to understand physical peak oil, the growing effort for
production must be considered. Physical peak oil occurs earlier, because the
overall efforts for production have increased, expanding production. [http://issuu.com/where-energy-meets-water/docs/mwh2o-
february2012/37 The energy agriculture connect], pp.36â38. Retrieved 18 February
2012, by Nicol-AndrÃ© BerdellÃ©, 4 February 2012 [http://www.prototype-
creation.de/real_energy.pdf Real energy and agriculture], original document.
Retrieved 18 February 2012, by Nicol-AndrÃ© BerdellÃ©, 16 October 2011

The aggregate production rate from an oil field over time usually grows until
the rate peaks and then declinesâsometimes rapidlyâuntil the field is depleted.
This concept is derived from the Hubbert curve, and has been shown to be
applicable to the sum of a nationâs domestic production rate, and is similarly
applied to the global rate of petroleum production. Peak oil is often confused
with oil depletion; peak oil is the point of maximum production, while depletion
refers to a period of falling reserves and supply.
headings: Peak Oil vs. Peak Cheap Oil
